comments:
build id: I20050219-1500
This has happened to me twice in the last few days after getting new build of
eclipse. When my program is running, the console will no longer stream the
output from stdout or stderr. The program, however, finishes to completion
(which took me a while to discover, and puzzled me a bit). 

If the line of code "System.out.println("test")" is the last line of the
program, and a breakpoint is set to this line, the debugger will stop at the
breakpoint to show that the line has been reached, however the line doesn't get
output to the console.
Intuition tells me that there is something to do with garbage collection messing
up here. If the object is out of memory while it is still streaming to stdout
then it messes up the console; although I cant imagine why the object would be
taken out of memory while it is still streaming to stdout. 

The first time it happened, I had coded something like:

while(true){
  SomeLargeObject obj = new SomeLargeObject();
  System.out.println(obj.toString());
  ...
  if (something) break;
}

The first few objects printed on the console, and then all of a sudden stopped
working. I tried "System.out.flush()" and it didn't work.
The problem was fixed itself when i did:

List<SomeLargeObject> objList = new ArrayList<SomeLargeObject>();
while(true){
  obj.add(new SomeLargeObject());
  System.out.println(obj.toString());
  ...
  if (something) break;
}

The problem has occured a second time, but I haven't located the "faulty" part
of my code that I could change to fix it. Nevertheless, it seems that the number
of characters that output to the console window before the console window stalls
depends on how much memory I have allocated elsewhere in my program. Thus, I
conclude the problem has something to do with eclipse. 

My program actually does run to completion and generate proper file output.

Sorry if I can't give my actual source code. 

I have also played around with the console buffer settings...nothing.

Also, have you tried outputting to a file (use the Common Tab on the launch config dialog)? Does the 
content of the file match the content of the console?

(In reply to comment #2)
> Are there any errors in your log (<workspace>/.metadata/.log)?

Here my log. There are a bunch of entries like this:

> Does this only happen when you use jdk 1.5? 
i only have used 1.5. 

Does the console view inform you that the process has terminated , ie does the
process name 
> become "<terminated> /foo/bar/java (date and time)" in your console? 
yes it does. it terminates and finishes to completion correctly. just stops
outputting to the console.

> Does your application produce the expected results when run from the command
line? 
will let you know when i try.

>What does SomeLargeObject.toString() do?
it represents a circuit. my program is a circuit partitioning algorithm. it uses
the ECJ library at http://cs.gmu.edu/~eclab/projects/ecj/ but i have never
experienced problems with that library. i think my objects might take up a lot
more memory than a GregorianCalendar object. The string that is generated in the
case might be very large in some cases, and is appended into a StringBuffer.
Hm... perhaps the console doesn't like strings in excess of 3K. No, it isn't
that (i don't think), I still had the problem when I only output tiny strings
for testing purposes. Also, it isn't the toString() method that I have
overloaded, I just used that as an example; we could call my method toMyString()
for clarity. 

> I've spent some time trying to reproduce your experience and so far have not
had any luck. 
hope this helps.

Please try running from the command line. We are unable to reproduce the 
problem using other tests cases. Please re-open if running from the command 
line works.
